definition: the final (of a syllable) (Chinese phonology)/rhyme/appeal/charm/(literary) pleasant sound

sentences.english: Is he trying to put messy lives into perfect prose?
sentences.chinese: 他是否正在尝试将混乱的人生提炼成完美的韵文？

sentences.english: His book was in parts written in verse.
sentences.chinese: 他的书有许多地方是用韵文写的。

sentences.english: Being able to chant fruits and review vocabularies of colors.
sentences.chinese: 会读诵水果韵文，并复习颜色的单字。

sentences.english: A dance is a measured pace, as a verse is a measured speech.
sentences.chinese: 舞蹈是一串有规则的步法，就如韵文是拟好的言语。

sentences.english: Literature usually takes the form of prose or verse.
sentences.chinese: 文学通常表现为用散文体或韵文体所写的文字形式。

sentences.english: And, by the incantation of this verse.
sentences.chinese: 请凭借我这韵文写就的符咒。

sentences.english: There were several versions of a verse.

sentences.chinese: 纸张背面的宇宙韵文在宇宙大学很受欢迎。

sentences.english: Not all verse is great poetry.
sentences.chinese: 并非所有的韵文都是伟大的诗篇。

sentences.english: The agreement and disagreement of verse and music with refined and popular tastes is an important factor that has influenced the development of the genre of Chinese verse.
sentences.chinese: 文乐的雅俗离合是影响中国韵文文体演变的重要因素。

sentences.english: Most of the play is written in verse, but some of it is in prose.
sentences.chinese: 这剧本大部份是用韵文写的，不过有一些是用散文。

definition: old language/the Classics/Classical Chinese as a literary model, esp. in Tang and Song prose/Classical Chinese as a school subject
Thousand Character Classic, 6th century poem used as a traditional reading primer
a pre-Tang Dynasty genre of poetry, relatively free in form, usually having four, five, six or seven characters per line
regular verse/strict poetic form with eight lines of 5, 6 or 7 syllables and even lines rhyming
Three Character Classic, 13th century reading primer consisting of Confucian tenets in lines of 3 characters
to rhyme/sometimes written 壓韻|压韵
a genre of poetry, developed in the Tang Dynasty, characterized by its strict form
abbr. for Shijing 詩經|诗经[Shi1 jing1], the Book of Songs
